talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 16 October 2003:

question.para: (1) What is the relationship between advice provided to regional bodies on implementation of national strategies through regional National Resource Management (NRM) Plans and the criteria/key elements used by the department to assess consistency with those national strategies.

(2) In respect of this advice (a) are the regional bodies finding it useful, (b) have the regional bodies provided feedback on it, and (c) does the department envisage the review of these national strategies in light of experiences in implementing these national strategies through the National Action Plan for Salinity and Water Quality (NAP) and National Heritage Trust (NHT).

(3) Are the protection and management of World Heritage Areas, Ramsar wetlands and other relevant matters of National Environmental Significance (NES) priorities for Commonwealth investment in implementation of regional NRM plans; if so, (a) will the Minister provide an example of how or where this is the case, and (b) has the Government formally issued advice to regional NRM plans on the Government's priorities for investment.

(4) Will the Minister explain how the accredited (a) Glenelg-Hopkins, (b) Mallee, (c) Mount Lofty Ranges, and (d) Greater Adelaide Regional Catchment Strategies implement key elements of the National Water Quality Management Strategy, the National Principles for the Provision of Water for Ecosystems and the National Framework for the Management and Monitoring of Australia's Native Vegetation.

(5) In respect of the press release dated 23 December 2002, (a) why did the Government continue to promote expenditure on a project that concluded in 1999-2000, and (b) why did the Government persist in promoting a project that degraded the environment and would no longer meet current funding guidelines.

(6) Are flood mitigation works being funded under any priority NAP or NHT projects; if so, in the Murray Darling Basin, do any of the draft or accredited NRM plans or investment strategies propose construction of flood mitigation works; if so, will NAP or NHT monies be spent on flood mitigation works.
(7) When will accredited NRM plans be made available on or through the NAP or NHT websites.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Australian Government, together with the relevant State or Territory, works with regional bodies to assist them to prepare regional NRM plans that meet both Australian Government and State/Territory requirements, including in relation to agreed national strategies. The Australian Government and states/territories also provide feedback to regional bodies on draft regional NRM plans against the accreditation criteria agreed multilaterally through the NRM Ministerial Council. These accreditation criteria are designed to ensure that NRM plans cover the full range of NRM issues, including consistency with agreed national strategies. In assessing a plan for accreditation, comment is sought from the policy areas within the Australian Government and states/territories with expertise on the full range of NRM issues, including those responsible for implementing agreed national strategies.

(2) (a) Yes,(b) Yes, and (c) National NRM strategies are subject to review according to the agreed terms of each strategy. For example, ongoing evaluation of progress towards the best practice native vegetation management arrangements described by the National Framework for the Management and Monitoring of Australia's Native Vegetation is due to occur once every three years.

(3) (a) Once a region's natural resource management plan has been accredited, regional bodies are responsible for developing investment strategies to attract investment in a regional plan. All Australian Government, state, territory and regional joint investment decisions for the National Action Plan for Salinity and Water Quality and the Natural Heritage Trust will be based on a region's investment strategy. An investment strategy will detail specific actions, costs and timeframes required to implement the plan and achieve regional NRM outcomes. Requirements include demonstrating the relationship with existing Government policies and programs. Governments will invest in these overall NRM outcomes rather than individual projects. The Australian Government assesses the balance of investments under an investment strategy in a particular region, including the areas for which the Australian Government has responsibility. Government investment in accredited NRM plans will be consistent with the goals and objectives of the relevant program:

investment under the National Action Plan for Salinity and Water Quality will focus on action to prevent, stabilise and reverse trends in salinity and to improve water quality and reliability that affects sustainable production, biodiversity and infrastructure;

investment under the Natural Heritage Trust will focus on actions which are consistent with the Trust's objectives relating to biodiversity conservation, sustainable natural resource use, and capacity building and institutional change.

Nationally agreed outcomes for the Natural Heritage Trust endorsed by all governments explicitly include matters of National Environmental Significance such as the protection and management of World Heritage Areas and Ramsar wetlands.

(b) Regional bodies have been advised that Australian Government investment in accredited NRM plans will be consistent with the goals and objectives of the National Action Plan for Salinity and Water Quality and the Natural Heritage Trust.

(4) Regional implementation of the National Water Quality Management Strategy, the National Principles for the Provision of Water for Ecosystems and the National Framework for the Management and Monitoring of Australia's Native Vegetation will be through the regional NRM plan, associated sub-regional plans (eg. regional vegetation management plans) and the regional investment strategy.

(a) Section 2.5 of the Glenelg-Hopkins Regional Catchment Strategy outlines the relationship between the Regional Catchment Strategy and the various regional sub-plans. With regard to river health and vegetation, consistent with national frameworks, the Regional Catchment Strategy summarises the values within these two asset classes and the corresponding threats and outlines management actions and targets. The Regional Catchment Strategy also indicates that further information is contained in the supporting sub-strategies.

The Regional Catchment Strategy and Native Vegetation Plan identify priority remnant vegetation assets and set forward a number of key actions and targets including cost-sharing and incentive schemes, enforcing native vegetation controls and developing regional guidelines for native vegetation retention based on the principle of net gain. Targets developed to date are to:
increase the overall cover of native vegetation to 30% of the catchment;
increase the cover of depleted Ecological Vegetation Classes (EVCs) to at least 15% of their pre-European vegetation cover by 2030;
double the cover of endangered EVCs.

The national water and water quality frameworks and strategies are being implemented by the Regional Catchment Strategy and the Glenelg-Hopkins River Health Strategy which deals with all aspects of surface water management for riverine environments. Each sub-catchment within the region is assessed for threats and risks to each valuable asset and actions proposed are based on maintaining priority assets (outlined in section 3.5 and then 5.3 of the Regional Catchment Strategy). Detailed waterway health targets are set out in Table 9 of the Regional Catchment Strategy (page 61).

(b) Implementation by the accredited Mallee Regional Catchment Strategy 2002-2007 of the key elements of the National Water Quality Management Strategy, the National Principles for the Provision of Water for Ecosystems and the National Framework for the Management and Monitoring of Australia's Native Vegetation will be achieved through activities driven by the following key Action Plans:
Biodiversity Action Plans;
Floodplain and Waterway Management Strategy;
Mallee Parks Management Plan;
Murray River Frontage Action Plans;
Native Vegetation Plan;
Rabbit Action Plan;
Regional River Health Strategy;
Salinity and Water Quality Management Plan; and
Weed Action Plan.

Examples of the achievable resource condition targets identified in the regional strategy that will be sought through Action Plans activities, and which are consistent with the key elements, are as follows:
improvement in water quality through reductions in the region's contributions to phosphorus and oxidised nitrogen loads in aquatic environments (National Water Quality Management Strategy);
an increase in environmental water entitlement (Principles for the Provision of Water for Ecosystems); and
an increased extent of each Ecological vegetation Class to at least 15% of pre-1750 extent (National Framework for the Management and Monitoring of Australia's Native Vegetation).

(c) and (d) Mount Lofty Ranges and Greater Adelaide is one region for the purposes of the National Action Plan for Salinity and Water Quality and the Natural Heritage Trust extension. The region's accredited plan sets out activities to implement the key elements under its programs for Managing Water for Improved Quality and Sustainability and for Managing Biodiversity. These programs propose a comprehensive suite of activities including benchmarking and monitoring, on ground actions, investigation and capacity building, all linked to resource condition targets. Actions are proposed for the following areas:
achieving water quality improvements (in terrestrial systems)
achieving water quality improvements (in coastal, estuarine and marine environments)
achieving sustainable water supplies
managing salinity
ecosystems: their maintenance, improvement and reconstruction
managing wetlands and watercourses
managing coastal, estuarine and marine ecosystems
managing urban biodiversity
protecting and managing threatened species and communities
managing pests and diseases in natural systems
managing fire for biodiversity gain.

(5) (a) Natural Heritage Trust assistance to the Swan Hill Rural City Council for flood mitigation is, along with other examples of assistance, a demonstration of the variety and breadth of support provided to communities under the Trust.

(b) The Swan Hill Rural City Council had Natural Heritage Trust funding of $458,000 approved over three years from 1997-98 to 1999-2000 for the Swan Hill Flood Mitigation Scheme. The project met the relevant years' Guidelines for funding under the Natural Heritage Trust. The last payment for this project was made in December 2002 and the final report was received in February 2003.

To be eligible for funding all Natural Heritage Trust proposals must be consistent with Australian Government and State statutory requirements and processes. The Swan Hill Flood Mitigation Scheme was reviewed by the Australian Government under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 (the Act). The review noted that the proposed scheme had been subject to assessment under the Victorian Water Act 1989 and concluded that the Victorian Government's assessment actions involved appropriate examination of environmental issues and identification of measures needed for environmental protection. The review therefore determined that neither an environmental impact statement nor a public environmental report was required for the purpose of achieving the object of the Act in regard to the proposed scheme.

While no specific environmental reports were undertaken or published in relation to this project, the Swan Hill Rural City Council consulted with a range of Victorian and New South Wales Government agencies including Parks Victoria. It is understood that none of these agencies raised any objections to the project from an environmental perspective.
The Swan Hill Rural City Council conducted an archaeological survey of the project site to address any indigenous cultural heritage concerns and issues.
(6) No flood mitigation works are being funded under any priority National Action Plan for Salinity and Water Quality or Natural Heritage Trust projects.

The Goulburn Broken Catchment Management Authority Regional Catchment Investment Plan for 2003-04 includes a proposal for $100,000 of National Action Plan funding to undertake preliminary work on the Lower Goulburn Floodplain scheme. This project seeks to resolve the flooding problems of the Lower Goulburn River by rehabilitation of the floodplain.

All projects in an investment plan will be assessed according to their contribution to jointly agreed NRM outcomes. Australian Government investment in accredited NRM plans and agreed investment strategies will be consistent with the goals and objectives of the relevant program:

investment under the National Action Plan for Salinity and Water Quality will focus on action to prevent, stabilise and reverse trends in salinity and to improve water quality and reliability that affects sustainable production, biodiversity and infrastructure;

investment under the Natural Heritage Trust will focus on actions which are consistent with the Trust's objectives relating to biodiversity conservation, sustainable natural resource use, and capacity building and institutional change.
(7) Accredited NRM plans are available through the Australian Government's NAP and NHT websites through links in media statements to regional bodies' websites.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 6 November 2003:

question.para: Has he or any other Minister asked any consultant or member of the public to consult with biofuel producers and refiner/marketers on the possibility of long-term contracts for biofuels; if so, (a) what terms of reference, if any, have been provided to either the consultant or individuals involved, and (b) will the details and the outcome of any discussions be made public.

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr Howard
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: I am advised that Mr Malcolm Irving AM was appointed on 14 August 2003 by the then Acting Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, the Hon Joe Hockey MP, as a facilitator to assist biofuels producers in their commercial negotiations with potential purchasers of ethanol. Mr Irving was not specifically asked to consult on the possibility of long-term contracts for biofuels, though this issue was not excluded by the Terms of Reference.
(a) The Terms of Reference under which Mr Irving was engaged are as follows:

(1) Meet as required with the fuel ethanol producers CSR Distilleries Operations Ltd and Manildra Energy Australia Pty Ltd and the oil companies Caltex Australia Limited, Mobil Oil Australia Pty Ltd, The Shell Company of Australia Ltd, BP Australia Pty Ltd and major independent fuel retailers and distributors and other parties you deem relevant to the objective, either separately or combined, for the purpose of brokering a commercial agreement or agreements for the supply and purchase of fuel ethanol for transport use.

(2) Identify any obstacles to brokering a commercial agreement or agreements for the supply and purchase of fuel ethanol for transport use; and identify actions the parties could take to address such obstacles.

(3) Provide an interim report to the Government through the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources as soon as practicable, but not later than Monday 15 September 2003, outlining any obstacles to achieving a commercial agreement or agreements for the supply and purchase of fuel ethanol for transport use, and including recommendations for action by the above mentioned fuel ethanol producers, oil companies and independent fuel retailers and distributors which could overcome any such obstacles.

(4) With a view to brokering a commercial agreement or agreements involving any of the above mentioned fuel ethanol producers, oil companies and major independent fuel retailers and distributors, facilitate the negotiation of mutually acceptable terms and conditions for the supply and purchase of fuel ethanol for transport use.

(5) Provide a final report to the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, not later than Tuesday 30 September 2003, subsequently extended to Friday 24 October 2003, outlining the outcomes of your discussions with the above mentioned ethanol producers, oil companies and major independent fuel retailers and distributors and progress towards brokering a commercial agreement or agreements for the supply and purchase of fuel ethanol for transport use; or outlining any obstacles preventing the brokering of such an agreement or agreements.

(b) The information provided in Mr Irving's report to Government was provided to him under deeds of confidentiality. The Government has been advised that this information is of a commercially sensitive nature and that disclosing its substance and the outcomes of discus-sions would represent a breach of confidence. On this basis the Government does not intend to release the report to the public.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 6 November 2003:

question.para: (1) Has he seen the Telstra Annual General Meeting (AGM) 2003 Notice of Meeting to be held on 14 November 2003 which was recently issued to all Telstra shareholders.
(2) Is he aware that Item 3 of the Items of Business proposes that the meeting approve an increase in directors' fees by $170,000 per annum from $1,150,000 to $1,320,000 per annum.

(3) To what degree are the current directors responsible for Telstra's $965 million write down of its Reach joint venture in Asia made in February 2003 and its reported poor market performance for the financial year ending 30 June 2003.
(4) Will he exercise the Commonwealth's 51 percent shareholding in Telstra and vote against the proposed $170,000 per annum increase in directors' fees; if not, why not.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) Item 3 of the Items of Business for the Telstra AGM proposed to consider and, if thought fit, to pass the following resolution as an ordinary resolution:

`THAT the maximum aggregate remuneration payable out of the funds of the Company to non-executive directors of the Company for their services as directors including their service on a committee of directors be increased by $170,000 per annum to $1,320,000 per annum'. That is it is a total increase in all directors' fees. On this basis, yes, I am aware of the resolution.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 6 November 2003:

question.para: (1) What is the definition of `matrimonial cause' in Commonwealth law.

(2) Can he explain the jurisprudential basis for the jurisdiction of the Family Court of Australia in respect of the ancillary relief jurisdictions of (a) Property Orders, (b) Maintenance Orders, and (c) orders for the care of children.
(3) What was the legislature's intent in creating Family Court jurisdiction over the matters enumerated in part (2).

(4) Is he aware of the editorial titled 'This deal is more than a bit Rich' in the Sydney Morning Herald on 5 November 2003 regarding the financial arrangements of the former One Tel Managing Director, Mr Jodie Rich and his wife Ms Maxine Rich.

(5) Is he concerned that the law appears to enable a person to use an agreement as a mechanism for putting significant assets beyond the reach of creditors by transferring to a spouse assets in excess of the spouse and their children's notional entitlements.

(6) Can he confirm that the legislation allows a person to pay in excess of the amount required to meet the financial needs of an estranged spouse and children, solely or substantially with the intention of placing assets out of the reach of his or her creditors.
(7) In drafting legislation, what procedure ensures that loopholes that enable people to avoid their obligations to creditors do not arise.
(8) Is he aware that Justice Stephen O'Ryan was precluded from accepting the petition of the Australian Securities and Investments Commission to recover part of an estimated $93 Million in assets.
(9) Does he intend to continue the policy of allowing binding financial agreements in family law.

(10) Does he intend to review the legislation that legalises binding financial agreements with a view to either (a) repealing these provisions, or (b) restricting such agreements to give them legal recognition only for the purpose of the recovery of debts by family court applicants; if so, when will this take place; if not, why not.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Attorney-General

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Subsection 4(1) of the Family Law Act 1975 defines `matrimonial cause' to mean:
(a) proceedings between the parties to a marriage, or by the parties to a marriage, for a decree of:
(i) dissolution of marriage; or
(ii) nullity of marriage; or
(b) proceedings for a declaration as to the validity of a marriage or of the dissolution or annulment of a marriage by decree or otherwise; or
(c) proceedings between the parties to a marriage with respect to the maintenance of one of the parties to the marriage; or
(ca) proceedings between the parties to a marriage with respect to the property of the parties to the marriage or either of them, being proceedings:
(i) arising out of the marital relationship;
(ii) in relation to concurrent, pending or completed proceedings between those parties for principal relief; or

(iii) in relation to the dissolution or annulment of that marriage or the legal separation of the parties to that marriage, being a dissolution, annulment or legal separation effected in accordance with the law of an overseas jurisdiction, where that dissolution, annulment or legal separation is recognized as valid in Australia under section 104; or

(d) proceedings between the parties to a marriage for the approval by a court of a maintenance agreement or for the revocation of such an approval or for the registration of a maintenance agreement; or

(e) proceedings between the parties to a marriage for an order or injunction in circumstances arising out of the marital relationship (other than proceedings under a law of a State or Territory prescribed for the purposes of section 114AB); or
(ea) proceedings between:
(i) the parties to a marriage; or
(ii) if one of the parties to a marriage has died—the other party to the marriage and the legal personal representative of the deceased party to the marriage;
being proceedings:
(iii) for the enforcement of, or otherwise in relation to, a maintenance agreement that has been approved under section 87 and the approval of which has not been revoked;
(iv) in relation to a maintenance agreement the approval of which under section 87 has been revoked; or

(v) with respect to the enforcement under this Act or the applicable Rules of Court of a maintenance agreement that is registered in a court under section 86 or an overseas maintenance agreement that is registered in a court under regulations made pursuant to section 89; or
(eaa) without limiting any of the preceding paragraphs, proceedings between the parties to a marriage with respect to a financial agreement made by them; or
(eb) proceedings with respect to the enforcement of a decree made under the law of an overseas jurisdiction in proceedings of a kind referred to in paragraph (c); or

(f) any other proceedings (including proceedings with respect to the enforcement of a decree or the service of process) in relation to concurrent, pending or completed proceedings of a kind referred to in any of paragraphs (a) to (eb), including proceedings of such a kind pending at, or completed before, the commencement of this Act.

(2) The jurisdiction of the Family Court of Australia is defined by reference to proceedings which are `matrimonial causes' (subsection 31(1)). Matrimonial cause is defined by subsection 4(1) referred to in (1) above. Property matters, maintenance matters and matters relating to the care of children come within this definition (paragraphs 4(1)(c), (ca), (f)). Section 39 provides for matrimonial causes to be instituted in the Family Court.

(3) At the time the Family Court was created State Courts were exercising jurisdiction in relation to matters which were within the definition of matrimonial causes. It was intended that matrimonial causes would be dealt with under the Family Law Act.
(4) Yes

(5) Yes. The Government prepared amendments to the Family Law Act to overcome the problems with the Family Law Act identified by the Family Court in the Australian Securities Investment Commission and Rich and Rich (No. SY 5067 of 2002) case in relation to the binding financial agreement provisions in the Act. These amendments passed the Parliament in the Family Law Amendment Bill 2003 on 5 December 2003 and commenced on 17 December 2003 with the Act receiving Royal Assent.

(6) The financial agreement provisions in the Family Law Act allow people to make agreements about the maintenance of either of them during the marriage, after the dissolution of marriage, or both during and after the dissolution of the marriage. There is a risk that a person could attempt to make an agreement to pay an amount in excess of the financial needs of an estranged spouse and children with the intention of placing assets out of reach of creditors. This is not the intention of the provisions. I announced to the House of Representatives on 5 December 2003 as part of the debate on the Family Law Amendment Bill 2003 that in light of the issues raised by the Rich case, I intend to undertake a review of the provisions relating to binding financial agreements. The purpose of the review is to ascertain whether the original intention of the provisions is being fulfilled.

(7) There is a range of mechanisms designed to minimise such risks, including consultation with stakeholders as part of the development of legislation and security by Parliamentary Committees. In addition, internal government processes in the development of legislation ensure scrutiny of the impact of the provisions and minimise this risk. Even these mechanisms do not always ensure that legislation is not able to be used for purposes for which it was not intended.

(8) I am aware that Justice O'Ryan decided in the Rich case that the Family Court does not have jurisdiction to deal with an application by a third party creditor to set aside a binding financial agreement where the interests of the third party are or may be adversely affected by the terms of the agreement.

(9) As noted in the response to Question (6), I announced to the House of Representatives on 5 December 2003 as part of the debate on the Family Law Amendment Bill 2003 that in light of the issues raised by the Rich case, I intend to undertake a review of the provisions relating to binding financial agreements. The purpose of the review is to ascertain whether the original intention of the provisions is being fulfilled.

(10) As indicated in my answer to Question (9), I intend to undertake a review of the provisions relating to binding financial agreements. I have asked officers of my Department to undertake this review as a matter of priority.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 6 November 2003:

question.para: In respect of the ruling on 4 November 2003 by Justice Stephen O'Ryan indicating that there was prima facie evidence supporting the Australian Securities and Investment Commission's claim that an agreement to shift assets, including the family home, to the wife of Mr Jodee Rich, Mrs Maxine Rich, was entered into because of a concern about claims on her husband's property by third parties as a result of the collapse of OneTel, when will the Government amend the Family Law Act to allow the Court to examine and overturn agreements made by parties to put assets out of reach of creditors.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Attorney-General

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: On 5 December 2003 the Government introduced amendments to the Family Law Act 1975 to overcome the issues identified by the Family Court in the Australian Securities Investment Commission and Rich and Rich (No. SY 5067 of 2002) case. These amendments provide the Family Court with the power to set aside a binding financial agreement on the application of certain third parties in circumstances where either party to the agreement has entered into the agreement for the purpose, or for purposes that included the purpose, of defrauding or defeating the interests of, or with reckless disregard for the interests of a creditor or creditors of the party. These amendments passed the Parliament in the Family Law Amendment Bill 2003 on 5 December 2003 and commenced on the Act receiving the Royal Assent on 17 December 2003.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 24 November 2003:

question.para: (1) Further to the answers to question Nos 358 (Hansard, 19 August 2002, page 4939), 884 (Hansard, 22 October 2002, page 8402), 1503 (Hansard, 14 May 2003, page 14574), 2079 (Hansard, 8 September 2003, page 18988), 2080 (Hansard, 8 September 2003, page 18988), 2081 (Hansard, 8 September 2003, page 18989) and 2456, will he contact the Director of Radiology at Concord Repatriation General Hospital to learn of the urgent need for a Medicare eligible Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) unit; if so, when; if not, why not.
(2) On what date was the last licence to operate a Medicare eligible MRI unit granted by his department and what are the details of this licence.
(3) Will Concord Repatriation General Hospital be granted a licence to operate a Medicare eligible MRI unit; if so, when, if not, why not.

talker.name: Abbott, Tony, MP
Mr Abbott
talker.role: Minister for Health and Ageing

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I met with the Chairman of the Medical Staff Council at Concord Repatriation General Hospital on 18 December 2003 to discuss this matter. My Department has also been in communication with the Hospital.

(2) The Australian Government does not issue `licences' to operate Medicare eligible units. Rather, it sets the conditions under which Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) services are eligible for Medicare rebates.

Six additional MRI units were approved for Medicare eligibility under the MRI Additional Units Eligibility Scheme as a result of a tender process completed in September 2001. These units were located in identified areas of need that had a sufficient population base to support MRI, but did not have close access to Medicare funded services.
The six units are located in:
Liverpool Public Hospital, Liverpool, NSW
Nepean Public Hospital, Kingswood, NSW
Orana Services, Orange, NSW
Dandenong Public Hospital, Dandenong, VIC
Nambour Public Hospital, Nambour, QLD
Gold Coast Public Hospital, Southport, QLD

Inner-west Sydney, where Concord Repatriation General Hospital is located, was not identified as an area of need, as there is relatively close access to Medicare funded MRI services in this area. In this regard, there are 13 Medicare eligible MRI units that are estimated to be within approximately half an hour's drive from Concord Repatriation General Hospital.
(3) No decision has been taken as to when, or if, MRI services at Concord Repatriation General Hospital will be eligible for Medicare rebates.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 24 November 2003:

question.para: In respect of the Council of Australian Governments agreement to a new Intergovernmental Agreement on water, (a) who will appoint the task forces, and (b) will State Governments be involved in the process.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (a) The Council of Australian Governments (COAG) has commissioned a group of Australian, State and Territory Government officials (known as the Senior Officials Group on Water, or SOGW) to develop a draft Intergovernmental Agreement for the National Water Initiative, for consideration at the first COAG meeting of 2004. The SOGW is chaired by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and each jurisdiction has appointed its own members. talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 24 November 2003:

question.para: (1) How many people in Australia are affected by Alzheimer's disease.
(2) Is he aware that a large number of people with Alzheimer's disease are being assisted by Aricept medication.
(3) Is he also aware that some people diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease are being denied subsidised access to the drug Aricept because they do not meet all the criteria that have been set.
(4) Would he consider reviewing the criteria so that all people who are using Aricept with some improvement in their condition will be allowed to continue receiving it on a subsidised basis.

talker.name: Abbott, Tony, MP
Mr Abbott
talker.role: Minister for Health and Ageing

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) It is estimated that almost 170,000 Australians currently live with some form of dementia, including early stage dementia. It is estimated that up to 70% of people living with dementia are affected by Alzheimer's Disease.
(2) For the year ending 30 September 2003, the number of patients assisted by subsidised access to AriceptR (donepezil) under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) was 18,087.

(3) The availability of Aricept on the PBS is restricted to patients with mild to moderately severe Alzheimer's disease who are able to satisfy certain criteria. The restriction was determined by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) with input from a panel of expert clinicians.

When making its decision on listing Aricept, the PBAC had to ensure that this drug was directed towards those patients in which it would be reasonably effective. Careful assessment of the health costs and benefits of a treatment is an important part of the PBS process.

(4) For Aricept to be made available as a pharmaceutical benefit for any further patient groups, an application providing sufficient supporting evidence would need to be submitted to the PBAC by the manufacturer of the medicine, Pfizer Pty Limited.

Neither the Australian Government nor the Committee is able to compel a manufacturer to apply for the listing of a particular product for a specific indication or patient group. Decisions on these matters involve commercial and other considerations that can only be made by the manufacturer involved.

subdebateinfo.title: Northern Victorian Fruit Growers Association: Funding Assistance
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2787)

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 25 November 2003:

question.para: In respect of the commitment by the Parliamentary Secretary for the Environment and Heritage that the Federal Government would provide funds to the Northern Victorian Fruit Growers Association for the purpose of helping engage a consultant to prepare background material for an Exceptional Circumstances application, when will the Government honour this commitment and what is the precise amount of funding to be provided.

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr Howard
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: I am advised that the Parliamentary Secretary for the Environment and Heritage, the Hon Dr Sharman Stone, did not provide an undertaking as suggested. The Australian Government does not provide funds to groups to engage consultants to prepare applications for Exceptional Circumstances (EC) assistance.

The Shepparton News ran a story reporting that Dr Stone and officials of my office had agreed to partially fund consultants to prepare drought and frost damage data for an application for EC assistance. Dr Stone's comments were misquoted by the journalist in question. I am advised that the journalist has acknowledged this mistake, in writing, and retracted his comments.

Under the EC guidelines, the States have agreed to prepare fully documented EC applications against all of the EC criteria, including demonstrating that there has been a severe and prolonged downturn in income, before an application is submitted to the Australian Government for consideration. Applications may be referred to the National Rural Advisory Council (NRAC) for assessment, which then makes a recommendation to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry.

Unfortunately, the Victorian Government has not met its obligations to its communities. For many of these drought and frost-affected producers it did not provide any direct State drought assistance, nor has it assisted the community in gathering the necessary information or submitted inadequate data.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 25 November 2003:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2281 concerning the individual who has been made bankrupt on twelve occasions, which specific provisions of the Bankruptcy Legislation Amendment Act 2002 change the law so that the Official Receiver is no longer compelled to accept a completed statement of a debtor's affairs.
(2) Is this power a discretionary power; if so, is it compellable or non-compellable.
(3) What is the policy rationale for the decision to make this power compellable or non-compellable.
(4) Is the power solely in the hands of the Official Receiver; if not, who else may exercise it.
(5) Is the power a statutory power exclusive of Executive prerogative; if not, what other Executive prerogative exists that empowers the Official Receiver not to accept a completed debtor statement.

(6) Has he issued any guidelines, policy statements, Ministerial directions or any other administrative instruments that clarify the operation of the Official Receiver's discretion whether to accept or not to accept a completed statement of debtors' affairs; if so, (a) when, and (b) what are the details; if not, why not.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Attorney-General

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Bankruptcy Legislation Amendment Act 2002 inserted subsections 55(3AA) and 57(3AA) into the Bankruptcy Act 1966. These provisions provide an Official Receiver with a limited discretion to reject a debtor's petition in specified circumstances.

(2) The power is discretionary and can be exercised only in the circumstances described in the provisions listed at part (1) of this answer. An Official Receiver cannot be compelled to exercise the discretion. Subsections 55(3AB) and 57(3AB) provide that an Official Receiver is not required to consider in each case whether there is a discretion to reject.

(3) The amendments were designed to prevent abuse of bankruptcy laws by some debtors. Bankruptcy laws are designed to provide relief to debtors with overwhelming debts. Therefore, there has never been an insolvency test for debtors wishing to present their own petition. This position was not addressed by these amendments. The circumstances in which an Official Receiver can reject a debtor's petition are intentionally limited to address only the most blatant abuses of the system (for example, debtors who use bankruptcy for an improper purpose simply to avoid paying their creditors). As such, it would be inappropriate to compel Official Receivers to consider in every case whether the discretion should be exercised.
(4) The discretion can be exercised only by an Official Receiver or a person to whom an Official Receiver has delegated the power under subsection 15(4) of the Bankruptcy Act 1966.
(5) Yes. The power is a statutory power exclusive of Executive prerogative.

(6) The Insolvency and Trustee Service Australia (ITSA) has issued a Best Practice Statement explaining how this discretion will be exercised. The Best Practice Statement explains the practical steps to be undertaken by an Official Receiver to determine whether the circumstances exist to support exercise of the discretion. The Best Practice Statement was issued on 17 April 2003. A copy of the Best Practice Statement is attached to this answer.

para.inline: The Best Practice Statement read as follows—
Exercising the discretion to reject a debtor's petition

answer.para: 1. A debtor's petition allows a person to voluntarily apply to become bankrupt. Subsection 55(1) of the Bankruptcy Act 1966 (the Act) allows a person to present a petition for his or her own bankruptcy. This allows a debtor who is overwhelmed by his or her debts to seek relief from payment of those debts.
2. A debtor's petition must be:
presented to an Official Receiver;
in the approved form; and
accompanied by a statement of the debtor's affairs.
3. Before accepting a debtor's petition, the Official Receiver must provide the debtor with the prescribed information.

4. The Official Receiver will examine the petition to ensure it complies with the formal requirements outlined above. If the petition does not comply with these requirements, the Official Receiver may reject the petition - subsection 55(3).

5. The Official Receiver also has a discretion to reject a debtor's petition where the petition amounts to an abuse of the bankruptcy system - subsection 55(3AA). This discretion is dealt with in more detail below.

6. Generally, unless the Official Receiver decides to reject the petition because it fails to comply with the formal requirements or because it represents an abuse of the bankruptcy system, the Official Receiver must accept the petition - subsection 55(4).

7. The Official Receiver has a discretion to reject a debtor's petition in limited circumstances. The Official Receiver is only able to reject those debtor's petitions that amount to a blatant abuse of the bankruptcy system. The circumstances that amount to a blatant abuse of the bankruptcy system are spelt out in the Act.
8. The circumstances where an Official Receiver can reject a debtor's petition are defined in the Act as follows:

it appears from the information in the statement of affairs (and any additional information supplied by the debtor) that, if the debtor did not become a bankrupt, the debtor would be likely (either immediately or within a reasonable time) to be able to pay all the debts specified in the statement of affairs; and
at least one of the following applies:

it appears from the information in the statement of affairs (and any additional information supplied by the debtor) that the debtor is unwilling to pay one or more debts to a particular creditor or creditors, or is unwilling to pay creditors in general;

before the current petition was presented, the debtor previously became a bankrupt on a debtor's petition at least 3 times, or at least once in the period of 5 years before presentation of the current petition.

9. The Official Receiver is not required to consider in each case whether to exercise this discretion - subsection 55(3AB). What this means is that the Official Receiver can simply accept a petition - there is no requirement that the Official Receiver considers whether or not to reject that petition.

10. Rejection of a debtor's petition will therefore be the exception rather than the rule. In the majority of cases, a petition will be accepted without the need for further inquiry. As noted above, only those petitions that amount to a blatant abuse of the bankruptcy system will be rejected.

11. In deciding whether to exercise this discretion, the Official Receiver is not required to determine whether or not the debtor is insolvent. Insolvency is not a pre-requisite for presenting a debtor's petition. The Official Receiver can reject a petition only in the limited circumstances described in the Act. The rationale for the discretion is to prevent a debtor from blatantly abusing the bankruptcy system by using it as a means to avoid paying debts when he or she has the capacity to pay those debts. Therefore, the Official Receiver is not deciding whether or not the debtor should or needs to become bankrupt or whether there is a better option available to the debtor. The Official Receiver is merely deciding that certain conditions are met which, according to the terms of the Act, give rise to a discretion to reject the debtor's petition.

12. Where the Official Receiver believes there may be a basis for exercising the discretion, the Official Receiver will contact the debtor to discuss his or her ability to pay. The Official Receiver will not make a decision without first consulting the debtor either in person, or by telephone. The Official Receiver is also to suggest that the debtor contact a financial counsellor, and will provide contact details for this purpose.

13. In considering whether to exercise the discretion, the Official Receiver will only take into account the information supplied in the statement of affairs, and any other information supplied by the debtor. The Official Receiver is unable to seek or consider information from other sources, eg. from creditors.

14. Where the Official Receiver rejects a debtor's petition, the debtor can apply to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) for a review of that decision - subsection 55(3AC). Only the debtor can apply to the AAT for a review of a decision to reject a debtor's petition. Neither a creditor nor anyone else can apply for review of a decision to accept (or reject) a debtor's petition.

para.inline: How will debtor's petitions be processed by ITSA?

answer.para: 16. There will be 3 stages in the processing of debtor's petitions. At stage one, processing officers will be looking for indicators that further investigation of the petition is warranted. Staff at this level will be looking for evidence of previous bankruptcies, or evidence that the debtor is unwilling to pay a particular creditor or creditors, or is unwilling to pay creditors in general. If any of these indicators are present, the officer may refer the petition to a more senior ITSA officer.

17. In the second stage, a more senior officer will consider whether there is evidence to indicate that the debtor would be likely to be able to pay all of his or her debts either immediately, or within a reasonable time. If the information supplied indicates this, the petition may be forwarded to the Official Receiver (or his or her delegate) to consider whether to exercise the discretion to reject a petition (the third stage).
These stages are explained in more detail below:
(i) Processing level: At this initial processing/ screening stage, staff will determine whether there is anything in the petition which indicates the need for further investigation.
The most obvious indicator is where:

A search on OTISS reveals that the debtor previously became a bankrupt on a debtor's petition at least 3 times, or at least once in the period of 5 years before the presentation of the petition. This is a question of fact. The debtor is required to provide details of previous bankruptcies in his or her statement of affairs.

However, where this appears to be the first time that the debtor has presented a petition, the officer should also look for evidence of the debtor's unwillingness to pay his creditors, or a particular creditor. This information may be contained in the statement of affairs, or in other information obtained from the debtor. The following indicators are relevant:
the debtor discloses that he or she is unwilling to pay a particular creditor;
the debtor appears to have been making payments to some but not all of his or her creditors;
the debtor has not explored the alternatives available to deal with his or her financial difficulties;
the debtor's view as to the cause of his or her insolvency;
the period of time over which the debtor has incurred debts;
evidence that the debtor has chosen to provide for an extravagant lifestyle whilst not making payments to creditors;

If one or more of these indicators are present in the petition or other information, the officer may forward the debtor's petition to a more senior officer for further consideration. If none of these indicators are present in the petition, there will be no further consideration of the discretion.

(ii) Further consideration level: officers at this level will need to determine whether there is evidence to indicate that, if the debtor did not become a bankrupt, the debtor would be likely (either immediately or within a reasonable time) to be able to pay all the debts specified in the statement of affairs. These circumstances may be indicated by information disclosed in the statement of affairs, or from other information supplied by the debtor. It is important to note that the question to be asked is `could the debtor pay all of his or her debts either immediately or within a reasonable time?' The fact that the debtor could meet minimum monthly or other payments would not be relevant.

18. It is at this point that the debtor should be contacted, and the suggestion made to the debtor that he or she seeks financial counselling. The contact details for financial counselling services should also be made available to the debtor.

19. What constitutes a reasonable time will depend upon the facts of each case. The circumstances which may indicate that the debtor could pay all of his her debts (immediately or within a reasonable time) include:
a disproportionate ratio of total amount of debts to actual income;
the debtor has an ability to make pay his or her debts immediately, either from cash reserves or by realising or encumbering an asset;

20. In these circumstances, the officer may forward the debtor's petition to the delegate of the Official Receiver. However; each case should be looked at in context. There may be other factors which will affect the debtor's ability to pay all of his or her debts either immediately or within a reasonable time. The following factors should be taken into account in each case:
the debtor's ongoing commitments (such as dependants);
recent changes in the debtor's circumstances which reduce his or her capacity to pay debts (such as loss of a job);

any exceptional circumstances affecting ability to pay (such as illness, special needs of dependants, loss of a second income in the household, sudden and unexpected loss of major assets including the debtor's home).

(iii) Decision level - by a Deputy Official Receiver, as delegate of the Official Receiver. This is the level where the delegate will need to determine whether or not to exercise the discretion to reject the petition. Where the relevant conditions as described above are met, the Official Receiver (or delegate) may reject the debtor's petition. However, it should again be noted that the Official Receiver is not required to consider in each case whether to exercise the discretion.

21. Where the Official Receiver rejects a debtor's petition, the Official Receiver will notify the debtor of this decision in writing providing reasons for rejecting the petition, and advise the debtor of the right to apply to the AAT for a review of the decision.

22. It will be necessary to keep accurate records of rejected debtor's petitions and associated material (the reasons for the decision) for two reasons: (i) the decision to reject the petition may be subject to review by the AAT, and (ii) the debtor may file another debtor's petition. However, in each case the decision to reject a petition must be based on the information supplied for the purposes of that petition. It is not acceptable to consider information supplied or obtained for a previously rejected petition. Each case must be decided on its own merits.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 4 November 2003:

answer.para: (1) No one has been extradited from Indonesia to Australia to face charges related to people smuggling. subdebateinfo.title: Family and Community Services: Child Care
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2803)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Children and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 27 November 2003:

question.para: (1) Can he confirm that cost pressures in 2004 will force up the cost of child care for full-time care to some $300 per week; if not, why not.

(2) Can he confirm that for a single parent with one child on an after tax income of $400 per week (a) the maximum amount of child care subsidy is approximately $140 per week; (b) an amount of $160 has to be paid by the parent, and (c) child care costs amount to 40% of disposable income; if not, why not.

(3) Can he confirm that many local councils which accepted grants for Child Care Centres under the Child Care Act 1972 now charge fees of up to $25,000 per year to community bodies who operate child care centres and bear the financial burden for operating child care services; if so, why is this acceptable; if not, why not.

(4) Would the cost of child care be reduced if local councils regarded child care centres, for which they have little or no financial responsibility, as a community service rather than a source of revenue; if not, why not.
(5) What action will he take to ensure local councils relieve financial pressure on child care centres so that they can provide affordable child care services to the community.

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr Anthony
talker.role: Minister for Children and Youth Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Government does not control the fees charged by child care services, but provides Child Care Benefit to all eligible families using approved child care.

Actual fee data from FaCS' Census of Child Care Services shows that average Long Day Care Fees in 2003, for 50 hours of care, are $194 per week. These fees have increased by less than one per cent or less than $2 a week, in real terms, from $192.23 in 1999.
(2) (a) Yes - the maximum rate of Child Care Benefit payable for a family with an income below $31 755 or receiving income support is $137 for 50 hours of care.
(b) The amount payable by the parent, after deducting CCB entitlement, will depend on the fees charged by the service.

For 50 hours of care, the average fee for Long Day Care is $194 and for Family Day Care $175. For a family receiving maximum rate of CCB, the average gap fee to be paid is $57 for Long Day Care and $38 for Family Day Care.
(c) The percentage of a family's disposable income spent on child care will depend on their Child Care Benefit entitlement and the fees charged by the service.

While fees represent a decreasing proportion of income as income rises, the effect of Child Care Benefit means that gap fees, on average, represent a similar part of the disposable income of a family, regardless of income. Families with an income of $50 000 pay child care fees of 11 per cent of disposable income for one child in full-time Long Day Care at average fees.
(3) I am not aware of the cases to which the honourable member refers.

The Child Care Act 1972 made available grants to the non-profit sector and local government for centre based child care. These were made under varying agreements with the recipient required to ensure proper acquittal of the funds provided.
Arrangements local councils enter into with child care service providers in their council area is a matter for their agreement.
(4) There is a range of factors that impact on the fees charged by individual services. The Government can not speculate on factors affecting fees in specific local government areas.

(5) The Government spent more than $7 billion on child care in its first 6 years in office. The Government has made a record allocation of around $8 billion over four years (to 2005-06) to support child care.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, upon notice, on 1 December 2003:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2470 (Hansard, 24 November 2003, page 22592), how effective is this policy in preventing departments and agencies retaining such legal practitioners.
(2) What legally binding effect and standing does this policy have at law.

(3) Can any person challenge at law an appointment of a barrister or solicitor, or other legal practitioner, by a Commonwealth Government agency where that legal practitioner has been previously declared bankrupt; if so, who; if no person can challenge the appointment, what action will he take to ensure that the law is changed such that those appointments may be challenged; if no action will be taken, why not.
(4) Will he recommend that this policy be given legislative force; if so, when; if not, why not.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The policy has been effective in that, as far as the department is aware, the services of no Barrister or Solicitor who has previously been made bankrupt have been retained.
(2) It has no legally binding effect or standing at law.
(3) Under paragraph 4.1 of the Attorney-General's Legal Services Directions, the Attorney-General could instruct an agency to change its lawyers.
(4) Changes to the law in relation to the engagement of Barristers and Solicitors by the Commonwealth are matters for the consideration of the Attorney-General.

talk.start.para: to ask the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 1 December 2003:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2479 (Hansard, 24 November 2003, page 22593), how effective is this policy in preventing departments and agencies retaining such legal practitioners.
(2) What legally binding effect and standing does this policy have at law.

(3) Can any person challenge at law an appointment of a barrister or solicitor, or other legal practitioner, by a Commonwealth Government agency where that legal practitioner has been previously declared bankrupt; if so, who; if no person can challenge the appointment, what action will he take to ensure that the law is changed such that those appointments may be challenged; if no action will be taken, why not.
(4) Will he recommend that this policy be given legislative force; if so, when; if not, why not.

talker.name: Macfarlane, Ian, MP
Mr Ian Macfarlane
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Records indicate that, as far as my department and portfolio agencies are aware, legal practitioners who use insolvency as a means of avoiding tax have not been retained.

(2) The policy referred to is legally binding under regulation 9 of the Financial Management and Accountability Regulations 1997. Regulation 9 states that the expenditure of public money must be in accordance with the policies of the Commonwealth.
(3) Yes. Under the Legal Service Directions, the Attorney-General can instruct an agency to change its lawyers if considered necessary (paragraph 4.1 of the Directions).
(4) This is a matter for the Attorney-General. Given my responses above, I do not consider it necessary to make a recommendation to the Attorney-General.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 1 December 2003:

question.para: (1) Does the Australian Federal Police have responsibility for the investigation of fraud committed by entities incorporated under the Corporations Act 2001?
(2) Is this an exclusive jurisdiction, or do State and Territory police forces also have jurisdiction for the investigation of fraud committed by these bodies?
(3) For each of the years between 1995 and 2003, how many convictions have there been for corporate fraud under Commonwealth legislation?
(4) Have resources, man power, or the level of experienced investigators allocated to the investigation of corporate fraud been reduced at any time since 1996?
(5) How does the Minister measure the allocation of resources within the Australian Federal Police for this purpose?

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Attorney-General

talk.start.para: —The Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes, the AFP has primary responsibility for the investigation of fraud committed by entities incorporated under the Corporations Act 2001, when such frauds constitute offences against Commonwealth legislation.

(2) This is not an exclusive jurisdiction. State and Territory police forces have jurisdiction to investigate fraud committed by these bodies where the offences are against State or Territory legislation.

Other Commonwealth agencies also have the authority and capacity to investigate fraud committed by entities incorporated under the Corporations Act 2001, in accordance with the Commonwealth Fraud Control Guidelines.
(3) The AFP is not in a position to answer this question. It should be referred to the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions for advice.

(4) The AFP does not have a specific team dedicated to the investigation of corporate fraud. Instead, a team will be formed to respond whenever a fraud referral is accepted by the AFP, with its skill levels matched to the specific requirements of the case. The level of resources allocated to the investigation of crimes of this type therefore fluctuates depending upon the complexity and priority of investigations on hand from time to time.

(5) Under the provisions of the Australian Federal Police Act 1979, the Commissioner of the AFP is responsible for the general administration of and the control of the operation of the AFP, and as such the allocation of resources is a matter for the Commissioner of the AFP. Consistent with other Commonwealth agencies, the AFP must account to Government on the funds appropriated to it and the outcomes and outputs achieved with this appropriation. The AFP reports to Government, through the Minister, on its performance by way of the AFP's annual report.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 4 December 2003:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2099 (Hansard, 9 September 2003, page 19075), in relation to the Call Centre and Training Facility at Bowen, on what date(s) were funds paid to the Bowen Collinsville Enterprise Group Inc, or any subsequent proponent, and how much was paid in each payment.
(2) What payment dates were included in the original contract for this project.
(3) What performance targets were established for each payment.
(4) If the Deed of Agreement was varied, in each case, what dates were set for payments and how much was set for each payment.
(5) If the Deed of Agreement was varied, in each case, what performance targets were established for each payment.
(6) What performance targets had been achieved on each occasion that payments were made.
(7) On what basis has final payment of this grant been made prior to final completion of the project.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) One payment of $92,400 (GST inclusive) was made on execution of the contract on 14 December 2001. A second payment of $347,600 (GST inclusive) was made on 27 June 2002.
(2) The first instalment was made on execution of the contract. The second and final instalment was linked to the acceptance of the first progress report, which was due on 30 March 2002.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 4 December 2003:

(3) Were any Federal Members of Parliament notified of the proposed flights; if not, why not.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
Mr Brough

answer.para: (1) The 4 Blackhawk Helicopters were taking part in a Special Operations Command counter terrorist training exercise. At all times the aircraft remained above their minimum required height above the highest obstacles.

subdebateinfo.title: Family and Community Services: Pension Bonus Scheme
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2866)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 4 December 2003:

question.para: (1) Is the Aged Pension Savings Bonus (APSB) an incentive for employees otherwise entitled to the aged pension to remain in employment; if so, why; if not, why not.

(2) Can the Minister confirm that the APSB cannot be claimed by an Australian over 65 years of age in full time employment if they had at any time previously been in receipt of an aged pension; if so, why; if not, why not.

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr Anthony
talker.role: Minister for Children and Youth Affairs

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) The question is referring to the Pension Bonus Scheme. The Scheme was introduced in July 1998 to encourage people to remain in the workforce and defer claiming Age Pension. The Scheme pays a tax-free lump sum to registered members when they claim and receive Age Pension.
(2) The legislation for the Pension Bonus Scheme does not allow a bonus to be paid to a person who has received an income support payment (other than Carer Payment) after age pension age.
This rule was introduced as the Scheme is not designed to draw people off Age Pension and back into the workforce.
